Hi @jboeuf I have some rough ideas that hopefully can be quick to implement:

---
The core C library, e.g., `grpc_ssl_pem_key_cert_pair`, is currently expecting `private_key` and `cert_chain` to contain PEM data.

What if we add the ability to alternatively take file paths, e.g., `private_key_file_path` and `cert_chain_file_path`?

Then every time a server SSL context is populated e.g., `populate_ssl_context()`, the `mtime`s of the two files are recorded. Then, somewhere in the library (I have not figured out the exact details, but I assume it's not too hard), on every new TCP connection from a client, the server checks the `mtime` of either file, and if either is newer than the corresponding recorded value, the server reconfigures the SSL context.

This way, the user simply updates the files on disk, and subsequent connections will use the new credentials.

(There is system clock change issue, but that might be an acceptable caveat.)

---
Another, perhaps more reasonable (?), approach is to add an API to the library that user applications can call to reconfigure/update the server's SSL context?


I can help with implementation of either solution or other solutions you prefer. Thoughts?

Thanks!

Hi @jboeuf @justinburke,

So this is what I've gathered:

---
During server initialization

- a `grpc_server_security_connector` is created once
  - it contains a `tsi_ssl_server_handshaker_factory` (created by `tsi_create_ssl_server_handshaker_factory_ex()`)
    - which contains the `SSL_CTX` populated from the PEM key/cert, cipher suites, etc. the user passed in (via a `grpc_ssl_server_config`)
- the `grpc_server_security_connector` is added to the channel args that are part of the `server_state` of the server "socket"

---
On each new accepted TCP connection

- the "server connection" is given a new `grpc_handshake_manager`
- `grpc_handshakers_add()` to add "server" handshakers to the newly created handshake manager
  - this eventually leads to a `ssl_server_add_handshakers()` call with the `grpc_server_security_connector`
    - down to `tsi_ssl_server_handshaker_factory_create_handshaker()` call with the `tsi_ssl_server_handshaker_factory`
      - and `create_tsi_ssl_handshaker()`, which creates `SSL` from `SSL_CTX`
- then the handshake manager performs handshakes

A key piece of code in `ssl_channel_add_handshakers()` (slightly modified):

```
void ssl_channel_add_handshakers(
  ...,
  grpc_channel_security_connector *sc,
  ...)
{
  tsi_handshaker *tsi_hs = NULL;
  tsi_ssl_client_handshaker_factory_create_handshaker(
      sc->handshaker_factory, ..., &tsi_hs);
```

So, to achieve the following:
> a more general approach with the caller being able to pass a credentials store object from which the SSL implementation can get keys/certs/roots each time a new handshaker is created.

is it reasonable to to do something like this---if the user chooses at server construction time, e.g., via certain flags/combination of values in server credentials object:

* `sc->handshaker_factory` will never be filled at all
* and then in `ssl_channel_add_handshakers()`, we do:

```
  tsi_handshaker *tsi_hs = NULL;
  if (sc->handshaker_factory) {
    tsi_ssl_client_handshaker_factory_create_handshaker(
      sc->handshaker_factory, ..., &tsi_hs);
  } else {
    // ask user for server credentials, create and use tmp handshaker factory
    grpc_ssl_server_config config = {0};
    tsi_ssl_server_handshaker_factory* tmp_handshaker_factory = NULL;

    int err = sc->get_server_credentials_callback(&config);
    // error checking

    tsi_ssl_client_handshaker_factory_create_handshaker(
      tmp_handshaker_factory, ..., &tsi_hs);

    /* free tmp_handshaker_factory. I do not know yet whether the
    handshaker factory has to stay around until the entire handshake
    is done, in which case, a modified approach is needed. */
  }

```

Regarding
> This is similar to your second approach but I would also like to avoid dependencies on OpenSSL internal objects since the TSI SSL interface could be implemented in terms of other underlying TLS libraries.

It seems the above approach would not violate this requirement?

Any feedback greatly appreciated! I'd be able to take a shot at implementing this if overall it seems ok to you!

Thanks!

>    /* free tmp_handshaker_factory. I do not know yet whether the
>    handshaker factory has to stay around until the entire handshake
>    is done, in which case, a modified approach is needed. */

hmm looks like the handshaker factory needs to stick around at least in case server SNI is used

@jiangtaoli2016 FYI

It is supported. You can create a TLS transport with a tls.Config object:
https://github.com/grpc/grpc-go/blob/master/credentials/credentials.go#L192
and set the GetCertificate callback in the config, which allows you to do the rotation:
https://godoc.org/crypto/tls#Config

What is not supported, AFAIK, is the ability to rotate the roots (no callback supplied).
